description: From Middle English emty, amty, from Old English ǣmtiġ, ǣmettiġ (“vacant, empty, free, idle, unmarried”, literally “without must or obligation, leisurely”), from Proto-Germanic *uz- (“out”) + Proto-Germanic *mōtijô, *mōtô (“must, obligation, need”), *mōtiþô (“ability, accommodation”), from Proto-Indo-European *med- (“measure; to acquire, possess, be in command”). Related to Old English ġeǣmtigian (“to empty”), ǣmetta (“leisure”), mōtan (“can, to be allowed”). More at mote, meet.
The interconsonantal excrescent p is a euphonic insertion dating from Middle English.

entries.meaning: Devoid of content; containing nothing or nobody; vacant.
examples: Synonyms: unoccupied, clear, (obsolete) leer, (rare dialect) toom, clean

entries.meaning: (computing, programming, mathematics) Containing no elements (as of a string, array, or set), opposed to being null (having no valid value).
(obsolete) Free; clear; devoid; often with of.
Having nothing to carry, emptyhanded; unburdened.
Destitute of effect, sincerity, or sense; said of language.
Destitute of reality, or real existence; unsubstantial.
Destitute of, or lacking, sense, knowledge, or courtesy.
(of some female animals, especially cows and sheep) Not pregnant; not producing offspring when expected to do so during the breeding season.
examples: Empty cow rates have increased in recent years.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, of a plant or tree) Producing nothing; unfruitful.
(usually plural) A container, especially a bottle, whose contents have been used up, leaving it empty.
examples: Put the empties out to be recycled.

verbs.description: empty (third-person singular simple present empties, present participle emptying, simple past and past participle emptied)

entries.meaning: (transitive, ergative) To make empty; to void; to remove the contents of.
examples: to empty a well or a cistern
The cinema emptied quickly after the end of the film.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a river, duct, etc: to drain or flow toward an ultimate destination.
examples: Salmon River empties on the W shore about 2 miles below Bear River.
